entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 7 at 3:55PM EST until March 10 at 11:40PM EDT by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Georgia...
Flint River near Lovejoy affecting Spalding, Clayton and Fayette Counties.
For the Flint River Basin...including Lovejoy, Americus, Peachtree City, Fayetteville, Peachtree City, Woolsey, Sharpsburg, Peachtree City, Peachtree City, Senoia, Griffin, Orchard Hill, Griffin, Molena, Thomaston, Carsonville, Montezuma, Byromville...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Flint River near Lovejoy.
* WHEN...Until late Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 12 feet, Flood Stage is reached and minor flooding begins. Flooding of Rivers Edge Golf Course begins. Several holes and fairways will flood. Flooding of some yards begins upstream of gage between Upper Riverdale Road and Highway 138.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:46 PM EST Thursday the stage was 11 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage Saturday afternoon to a crest of 13.4 feet early Sunday morning. It will then fall below flood stage Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 12 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clayton, GA; Fayette, GA; Spalding, GA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE SUNDAY EVENING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 7 at 3:51PM EST by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Oconee River near Oconee affecting Wilkinson, Johnson and Washington Counties.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Oconee River near Oconee.
* WHEN...From Saturday morning until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 17.0 feet, Flood stage is reached. The water level reaches the top of the Old Balls Ferry Road boat ramp...just upstream and along the right bank from the Georgia Highway 57 bridge. Minor flooding of woodlands near the river occurs.
At 21.0 feet, Moderate flooding begins. The dirt parking lot by the Old Balls Ferry Road boat ramp is under one to three feet of water. The end of Old Balls Ferry Road begins to flood. Flooding continues and spreads further into the woodlands near the river.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:30 PM EST Thursday the stage was 13.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage Saturday morning and continue rising to a crest of 19.9 feet early Sunday afternoon. It will then rise to 21.2 feet Tuesday morning. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Johnson, GA; Washington, GA; Wilkinson, GA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY MORNING UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 7 at 3:47PM EST until March 10 at 1:00AM EST by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of northwest Georgia, including the following counties, Catoosa, Dade, Walker and Whitfield.
* WHEN...From Friday evening through late Saturday night.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A storm system will produce moderate to heavy rainfall in the region between Friday night and Saturday night. Rainfall totals of 2 to 4 inches are expected, with locally high amounts possible. This rainfall combined with saturated soil conditions will likely produce flooding. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY EVENING THROUGH LATE SATURDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 7 at 2:36PM CST until March 7 at 8:00PM CST by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING FOR ALL OF SOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO, THE NORTHWEST PERMIAN BASIN, AND THE UPPER TRANS PECOS SOUTH TO THE PRESIDIO VALLEY FOR RELATIVE HUMIDITY OF 15% OR LESS, 20-FT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR MORE, AND HIGH FIRE DANGER...
* TIMING...This afternoon and evening.
* WINDS...West 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph in the mountains.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 10 percent.
* RFTI...5 or 6 or critical.
* IMPACTS...Avoid the use of open flames or any activities that may generate sparks. Accidental ignitions will have the potential to grow into dangerous wind-driven wildfires.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 7 at 2:11PM CST by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
A period of steady rainfall is expected to move into the area on Friday, lingering into the evening. Widespread rainfall amounts up to one inch are possible across northeast Illinois and northwest Indiana, with amounts of 1-2 inches possible in isolated areas. Dormant vegetation and elevated soil moisture conditions will reduce infiltration and allow for much of this rainfall to runoff into area streams and rivers.
Ensemble river forecast guidance indicates the possibility of multiple rivers reaching bankfull due to this rainfall. Urban areas and poor drainage areas may also experience areas of standing water. While widespread flooding is not likely, a few river locations may near flood stage by this weekend.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and advisories.
An update to this outlook will be issued by tomorrow morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cook, IL; DuPage, IL; Ford, IL; Grundy, IL; Iroquois, IL; Kankakee, IL; Kendall, IL; La Salle, IL; Livingston, IL; Will, IL; Benton, IN; Jasper, IN; Lake, IN; Newton, IN; Porter, IN

If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.
Cloud to ground lightning are occurring with these storms. Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe shelter inside a building or vehicle.

entry.summary:

* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 3 PM ChST Monday. For the Coastal Flood Statement, from this afternoon through Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is being supported by a large trade-wind surge that extends eastward to Hawaii. With the upcoming King Tides around March 10th, minor coastal inundation is expected starting this afternoon, especially during high tide. Greatest risk will be along shores exposed to the northeast to east across the Marshall Islands since surf and tides will be higher around the Marshall Islands. Please report any inundation to the local Weather Service Office (WSO).

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 7 at 10:49AM CST until March 8 at 4:00PM CST by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
...A FIRE WEATHER WATCH IS IN EFFECT FRIDAY LATE MORNING AND AFTERNOON FOR LOCATIONS ALONG AND WEST OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 69C...
.A dry cold front ushers in rapidly lowering relative humidity and moderate to gusty winds elevating the fire danger for potential rapid growth and spread of any wildfires that may get started.
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has issued a Fire Weather Watch for Zapata, Jim Hogg, Brooks, Starr, and Hidalgo Counties, which is in effect from late Friday morning through Friday afternoon.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 248 Zapata, Fire Weather Zone 249 Jim Hogg, Fire Weather Zone 250 Brooks, Fire Weather Zone 252 Starr, Fire Weather Zone 253 Southern Hidalgo and Fire Weather Zone 353 Northern Hidalgo.
* TIMING...11 AM CST to 4 PM CST.
* WINDS...North to northwest 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 88.
*LIGHTNING...NONE.
* IMPACTS...Rapid spread of wildfire on drying grasses and brush is possibly Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Zapata; Jim Hogg; Brooks; Starr; Southern Hidalgo; Northern Hidalgo

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 3:17AM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A deep arctic trough will move south over the Western Interior and West Coast and bring well below normal temperatures beginning Friday night. High pressure over the Chukchi Sea will bring strong north winds starting Friday night as well. Low temperatures by Saturday morning will be in the teens and 20s below zero and remain that way through Wednesday morning. Highs will range from near zero to 10 below. North winds of 10 to 30 mph with higher gusts will bring wind chills as low as the 40s to near 50 below zero.
Residents and those traveling in the area are encouraged to be prepared for much colder than normal conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Slopes of the Western Brooks Range; Noatak Valley; Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Upper Kobuk Valleys; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast; Lower Yukon River; St Lawrence Island; Lower Koyukuk Valley; Middle Yukon Valley; Lower Yukon and Innoko Valleys

* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 2 and 5 inches. Higher amounts possible over Bartlett Mesa east of Raton Pass. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass.
* WHEN...From 5 PM this afternoon to 11 PM MST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Areas of blowing snow may reduce visibility to less than one mile at times. Travel could be difficult. This includes along portions of I-25 through Raton Pass.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 6 at 3:01PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
ESFBIS
Given the recent cold weather, the Missouri River has again been forming ice below Garrison Dam. Thus far, ice has filled the recently cleared portion of the Missouri River from roughly Apple Creek Wildlife Management Area to about three-fourths of a mile upstream of where 12th street southeast turns into Oahe Bend. This would roughly be equal to a little less than five miles of new ice in the river.
The upstream edge of immobile ice as of Wednesday morning was roughly three and a half miles downstream of Fort Abraham Lincoln and Fox Island. While the future rate of ice formation is difficult to predict, forecast overnight lows in the single digits for both Thursday and Friday mornings will continue to encourage ice formation. It should be expected that the upstream edge of continuous ice on the river will migrate upstream. Based on how much ice has already been put in place, it is possible that the upstream edge of continuous ice will reach the Fox Island area before warmer weather enters the area on Friday. By late Saturday, warmer weather will once again reverse this process and start removing ice.
Importantly, pre-ice river levels were about 3.5 feet below that observed prior to last week's ice jam due to already planned lower releases out of Garrison Dam. This suggests that a return to water levels experienced in late February is not likely.

cap:parameter.value: MISSOURI RIVER IS ONCE AGAIN MAKING ICE
